Description.En:
The Smart Machining micromodule is designed to equip you with cutting-edge knowledge and practical skills in the field of advanced manufacturing. By taking this micromodule, you will delve into the sophisticated techniques that underpin smart machining.

The course is divided in two parts: three modules of 6 hours each and a project for analysing the experimental data. Each module is composed of 2 hours of online classes and 4 hours of assignment with the professor. The project is composed of 8 hours of synchronous work and the students should be able to work on the project between each week to evaluate its personal task in the group. The evaluation is part based on the assignments and part on the project work. By the end of the module, we expect that the students are convinced that the data can be useful to improve productivity on industry in practice.

By the end of the module, students will possess an understanding of smart machining technologies and their practical applications. This knowledge will empower them to contribute to the advancement of manufacturing processes, making them valuable assets to any industry focused on innovation and efficiency. The skills acquired in this course will prepare students for roles in advanced manufacturing, process optimization, and industrial automation, positioning them at the forefront of the smart manufacturing revolution.

Title.En: Predict the lobe diagrams using mechanistic aproach
Understand the data format taken from machines (json and xml)

NoteLiteral.En: You will also be able to understand how the network for acquistion works.

Title.En: Work in an international team to propose a machining process and analyse experimental data

PrefLabel.En: using digital tools to control machinery

NoteLiteral.En: You will collaborate with team members to determine a machining process for your team's case study, and then analyse the experimental data from a real machining process.

Title.En: Predict forces in a simplified machining operation compiling a basic programming code.

LegalName.En: INSTITUT NATIONAL DES SCIENCES APPLIQUEES DE TOULOUSE (INSA TOULOUSE)

Description.En: You will complete personal assignments online relating to a range of processes and phenomena central to smart machining.

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
**Format and Structure**

Whilst folowing this course, you will study both material online at your own pace as well as engage with synchronous live sessions with your professor and peers. The online live sessions will take place on a fixed day (either Mondays, Tuesdays, or Wednesdays), in the morning. You will have 2-3 hours of live sessions during a week. Sessions will be recorded so if you cannot attend the sessions, you can catch up independently. However, please note that some sessions (such as your evaluation session) will be mandatory. Check with your professor at the beginning of the micromodule.

The online sessions will follow the structure below:

- Class 1 (1h) - Introduction and Force modelling,
- Class 2 (2h) - Exercise on class of prediction of cutting force (assignment)
- Class 3 (1h) - Dynamic of cutting
- Class 4 (1h) - Exercise on lobes diagram A
- Class 5 (1h) - Exercise on lobes diagram B (Assigment)
- Class 6 (1h)- CNC machine-tool set-up and acquisition
- Class 7 (1h) - Exercise on analysing CNC data (pyhon/Mongo Compass)
- Class 8 (1h) - Assignment about the combined different data in the same time scale
- Class 9 (2h) - Project part 1
- Class 10 (2h) - Project part 2
- Class 11 (2h) - Project part 3
- Class 12 (2h) - Project part 4

**Evaluation**

Your evaluation grade is composed of 60% assignment work and 40% final group project. You will either receive a pass or fail for this module.

For the final group project, you will collaborate remotely with international team members to determine a machining process for your team's case study, and then analyse the experimental data from a real machining process. Students at INSA Toulouse will operate the machines and ECIU students will analyse the data, helping students gain an understanding of what it's like to work in an international and geographically-dispersed team. You will submit a video presentation via Moodle presenting your case study and data analysis.
Analysing and improving the industrial machining process

The Smart Machining micromodule is focused on the advanced techniques of Computer Numerical Control (CNC) in 5-axis machines. Through practical examples and hands-on projects, participants will learn how smart machining technologies can drive innovation and competitiveness in industry. The courses introduces the various types of sensors used in these systems and how they can contribute to process optimisation. You will learn about communication protocols with CNC machines, the integration of sensors' response with the database, and how you should carry out impactful data analysis. You will explore cutting forces and their impact on machining processes, learning to predict these forces for improved outcomes. The course also examines machining dynamics, providing insights into vibration and stability. Finally, a significant focus is placed on data analysis, collecting and interpreting machining data for continuous improvement and predictive maintenance.

In order to be eligible for this micromodule, you should have a basic understanding of machining, mechanical vibration, and CNC programming. You should also have a basic understandng of either Python or MATLAB.

During the application process you will be asked to provide a transcript of records and CV that should demonstrate your skills in these areas.
